<svg width="18" class="size-5" height="18" viewBox="0 0 48 48" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15 8C8.92487 8 4 12.9249 4 19C4 30 17 40 24 42.3262C31 40 44 30 44 19C44 12.9249 39.0751 8 33 8C29.2797 8 25.9907 9.8469 24 12.6738C22.0093 9.8469 18.7203 8 15 8Z" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="4" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="bevel"/></svg>
Meraki UI is an open-source collection of Tailwind CSS components and templates. It offers a range of pre-designed UI elements and layouts that can be used to quickly build web interfaces.

Use Meraki UI when you want to accelerate your Tailwind CSS development process with a set of pre-designed components and templates. It's suitable for projects where you want to quickly prototype or build web interfaces with a consistent design.

Avoid Meraki UI if you require a component library with extensive customization options or highly specific designs. Also, if you prefer a component library with built-in theming capabilities, Meraki UI might not be the best choice.
Meraki UI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
Meraki UI has 31 Components, 18 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
Meraki UI has light and dark themes
Does not support more than 2 themes at the same time
Meraki UI has no dependencies, but it requires Alpine.js
Meraki UI uses Tailwind CSS class names which is available on CDN
Meraki UI does not use semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
Meraki UI requires changing class names one by one at build time to do customization
Meraki UI does not requires a Node.js environment
Meraki UI does not provide micro CSS files for each component
Meraki UI does not use wide-gamut P3 colors by default
Meraki UI customizations requires changing Tailwind CSS class names at build time
Meraki UI doesn not use native CSS nesting

daisyUI is a component library for Tailwind CSS that provides pre-designed components with theming capabilities. It is framework-agnostic, meaning it can be used in any web project, and it doesn't ship any JavaScript to the browser.

Use daisyUI when you want to rapidly prototype or build a project with a consistent design system based on Tailwind CSS. It's well-suited for projects where you need a large variety of customizable components and theme options without writing a lot of custom CSS.

Avoid daisyUI if you need highly specific or unique component designs that deviate significantly from the pre-designed styles. Also, if you prefer to build all components from scratch for maximum control over every detail, daisyUI might not be the best choice.
daisyUI is framework agnostic and works everywhere
daisyUI has 63 components, 59 of them are unique – for example pagination and button group are considered as same.
daisyUI supports unlimited themes at the same time, allowing for dynamic theme switching.
daisyUI doesn't ship JavaScript to browsers
daisyUI has no dependencies. It's immune to 3rd party vulnerabilities, dependency version mismatch, and deprecation issues.
In GitHub's top 400 repositories of all time
daisyUI CSS file is available on CDN
daisyUI uses semantic CSS class names. Using semantic and descriptive CSS class names improves readability and maintainability of code independent of the current framework.
daisyUI provides tokens, root-level CSS variables and component-level CSS variables that let you adjust colors, sizes, spacing, radius, and other styles to match your design.
daisyUI can be used as a standalone file, with Tailwind CSS standalone version. This is useful for projects without a Node.js environment.
daisyUI provides micro CSS files for each component
daisyUI uses CSS variables for design customization at runtime
daisyUI uses native CSS nesting, reducing the CSS file size
Tasks that might be easier with daisyUI compared to Meraki UI

Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Meraki UI on GitHub. Meraki UI offers a good selection of components. daisyUI offers a wider selection compared to Meraki UI. daisyUI runs as a self-contained plugin for Tailwind CSS
Meraki UI offers a good selection of components. daisyUI offers a wider selection compared to Meraki UI.
daisyUI's architecture is built around runtime theming using CSS variables. Meraki UI usually relies on build-time theme generation.
Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Meraki UI on GitHub. Many projects rely on daisyUI, as shown by its substantial download numbers
Developers often use stars to bookmark projects. More developers have chosen to star daisyUI over Meraki UI on GitHub.
Many projects rely on daisyUI, as shown by its substantial download numbers.
daisyUI runs as a self-contained plugin for Tailwind CSS.
daisyUI adds components to Tailwind CSS with a philosophy centered on CSS. This contrasts with Meraki UI, which often integrates more deeply with JavaScript frameworks.
